conclusion: The problem involves using a current balance to measure the magnetic induction intensity of a uniform magnetic field, with a rectangular coil in the field and weights used to balance the system.

The image shows a current balance with a rectangular coil in a magnetic field. The coil has horizontal side length \( l \), and the magnetic field is perpendicular to the plane of the coil. The balance has weights on both sides.
When a current \( I \) passes through the coil, weights are adjusted to balance the two arms. Reversing the current requires adding a weight \( m \) to the left pan to balance the system again.

The force on the coil due to the magnetic field when the current is in one direction is equal to the force when the current is in the opposite direction, plus the additional weight required to balance the system.

The force on each side of the coil is given by \( F = nBIl \), where \( n \) is the number of turns, \( B \) is the magnetic field strength, \( I \) is the current, and \( l \) is the length of the side of the coil.
Since there are two sides of the coil, the total force on the coil is \( F_{\text{total}} = 2nBIl \).
When the current is reversed, the force on each side of the coil will be in the opposite direction, so the total force on the coil is \( F'_{\text{total}} = -2nBIl \).
Initially, the system is in balance, so the forces on the two arms are equal. After the current is reversed, an additional weight \( mg \) is needed to balance the system.
The difference in the forces is equal to the weight of the additional mass: \( |F_{\text{total}} - F'_{\text{total}}| = mg \).
Substituting the expressions for the forces, \( |2nBIl - (-2nBIl)| = mg \).
Solving for \( B \), we get \( B = \frac{mg}{4nIl} \).
The magnitude of the magnetic induction intensity \( B \) is \( \boxed{\frac{mg}{4nIl}} \).
